title: R43453
content: The renewable electricity PTC is a tax credit for electricity generated using qualified energy resources, sold to an unrelated person. The credit can be claimed for 10 years once a qualifying facility is in service. The maximum credit amount varies by year and technology type. Nonwind facilities may qualify if construction began before January 1, 2018, while wind facilities must begin construction before January 1, 2020. The Production Tax Credit (PTC) applies to renewable energy facilities, with reduced credits for certain facilities. The credit amount decreases based on the year construction begins. The PTC has not been phased out due to electricity market prices not exceeding threshold levels. The corporate alternative minimum tax (AMT) has also impacted the ability to claim the PTC in the past. The Production Tax Credit (PTC) has not been phased out as market prices of electricity have not exceeded threshold levels. The corporate alternative minimum tax (AMT) previously limited the ability to claim the PTC, but this limitation was eliminated in the 2017 tax revision. Additionally, PTC-eligible taxpayers had the option of claiming the 30% energy investment tax credit (ITC) or an American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) Section 1603 grant in lieu of tax benefits from 2009 to 2017. From 2009 to 2017, PTC-eligible taxpayers could choose the 30% energy investment tax credit (ITC) instead of the PTC. Property placed in service during 2009-2011 had the option of an ARRA Section 1603 grant. Production tax credits are available for Indian coal and refined coal, with specific requirements for eligibility and credit amounts. Indian coal facilities must have been in service before 2009 for credits. The base rate for Indian coal is $2.00 per ton, while refined coal has a base credit amount of $4.375 per ton. Credits are not available for coal produced after 2017. The Production Tax Credit (PTC) was first enacted in 1992 as part of the Energy Policy Act of 1992. It has been extended 11 times since 1999. Initially available for wind and closed-loop biomass systems, it was later extended to include poultry waste. The PTC was extended through December 31, 2003, and further extensions were made in subsequent acts.
